div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Glasgow merchant John Stark, September 6, 1729, to inform him of a bill of Exchange that Carter has drawn on him.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Stark, September 6, 1729

opener.dateline:
Rappa[hannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr. 6th. 1729
Mr John Stark

div1.p:
This is only a line to advise you of a bill
of Exch. I have this day drawn upon you for Two hundred
pounds Sterling payable to Doctor George Nicholas which
I desire you to Answer at time on my Accot. And that you will
contrive the paymt: of it without any loss to the Recevr. as you
tell me for the most part you Can I am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] John Stark was a merchant, probably the one to whom Carter referred when he wrote to Micajah Perry on 1723 July 4 that he had drawn an order on "Mr. Stark of Glasgow." On that same day, he wrote to a John Stark, referring to Captain Bowman.
